newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares in late rally, index ends 1.7 pct up.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares in late rally, index ends 1.7 pct up.

text.p: A late rally led by pivotal stocks helped Bombay bourses finish near the day's highest levels on Tuesday, with the benchmark Bombay index closing above the 3,500 mark, dealers said.
The benchmark 30-share index of the Bombay Stock Exchange jumped 60.08 points, or 1.74 percent, to end at a provisional 3,503.63--the intra-day high.
Participants said speculation the federal budget due on February 28 will contain market friendly measures prompted buying.
"With growing expectations about the budget, more players are entering the market," said chief dealer Ketan Jhaveri at brokerage Kotak Securities.
Some funds were keen buyers in cement stocks in anticipation of incentives likely to be given to the industry, traders said.

Cement maker ACC rose 80.75 rupees, or 5.83 percent, to 1,465.0 in volumes of 121,531. Gujarat Ambuja Cement which last week announced a 20 percent rise in net profit for the first half ending December 1996 jumped 9.25 rupees, or 3.79 percent, to 253.25 with 431,659 shares traded.
"The market has shown a steady rise today. It is more due to operators building up positions ahead of the budget," said Ravi Chadha, institutional dealer at brokers Motilal Oswal.
Kotak's Jhaveri said, "The nominal arbitrage opportunities between Bombay bourses indicates that operators are taking delivery based positions."
In the list of pivotal stocks, SBI gained 11.50 rupees to 282.75, TELCO 13.20 to 333.0, L&T 6.75 to 247.25, ITC 7.75 to 408.75 and Reliance 4.50 to 278.0.
"This is a pre-budget euphoria that we are seeing. A short-term rally is likely to prompt fence-sitters to build up fresh positions," said a dealer at a foreign brokerage.
"Foreign funds however, are not aggressive buyers," he said.
The 50-stock National Stock Exchange index ended 12.60 points higher at 994.05, off the day's highest level of 996.05.
